bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 3, 1900

div1.p: Reed will leave New York for Havana soon.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 3, 1900
div1.opener:
Grand Hotel
Broadway E. 31st St.
New York.
William G. Leland.
Novr 3, 1900
My darling wifie;
div1.p:
When I got up,
this morning, after a good night's
rest, and went out to Broadway,
imagine my surprise to find
that it was raining and that
the day was a dreary, rainy,
miserable dayone, instead of the
beautiful, bright day that
we had expected- I was, to
say the least, dreadfully dis-
appointed- I didn't let this
prevent me from enjoying
my break fast, and as I have
my rubbers conveniently
near, I am well-prepared
for the dampness- I hope that
my sweet girls slept well
last night. What Dear bed-
fellows they should make!
It is such a comfort to me
to know that precious little
joy is taking such an interest
in her studies and that dear,
sweet mother is helping her
with her lessons with so,
much interest too- I wouldn't
take a great deal for that
picture ofthose my girls study-
ing their lessons together!
My steamer is scheduled to reach
Havana, early Wednesday morn-
ing, so that I expect to get a letter
in the mail that leaves at noon
of that day (Novr 7th)- Write as
often as you can, & sweet cocoon
must do the same- Love and kisses
for my precious babies-
